TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mycenaean civilization flourished between 1600 BC and ca. 1100 BC, when it perished with the collapse of Bronze-Age civilization in the eastern Mediterranean. The collapse is commonly attributed to the Dorian invasion, although other theories describing natural disasters and climate change have been advanced as well. The major Mycenaean cites were Mycenae and Tiryns in Argolis, Pylos in Messenia, Athens in Attica, Thebes and Orchomenus in Boeotia, and Iolkos in Thessaly. In Crete, the Mycenaeans occupied Knossos. In addition there were some sites of importance for cults, such as Lerna, typically in the form of house sanctuaries. Mycenaean settlement sites also appeared in Epirus, Macedon, on islands in the Aegean, on the coast of Asia Minor, and then in Cyprus. Mycenaean artifacts with Linear B inscriptions have been also found as far away as Germany and Mycenaean swords as far away as Georgia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mycenaean civilization was dominated by a warrior aristocracy. Around 1400 BC, the Mycenaeans extended their control to Crete, center of the Minoan civilization, and adopted a form of the Minoan script (called Linear A) to write their early form of Greek in Linear B. Not only did the Mycenaeans defeat the Minoans, but according to later Hellenic legend they twice defeated Troy, a powerful city-state that rivaled Mycenae in power. Because the only evidence for the conquests is Homer's Iliad and other texts steeped in mythology, the existence of Troy and the Trojan War is uncertain. In 1876, the German archaeologist Heinrich Schliemann uncovered ruins at Hissarlik in western Asia Minor (modern-day Turkey) that he claimed were those of Troy. Some sources claim these ruins do not match well with Homer's account of Troy, but others disagree.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Mycenaeans buried their nobles in beehive tombs (tholoi), large circular burial chambers with a high vaulted roof and a straight entry passage lined with stone. They often buried daggers or some other form of military equipment with the deceased. The nobility were frequently buried with gold masks, tiaras, armor, and jeweled weapons. Mycenaeans were buried in a sitting position, and some of the nobility underwent mummification, whereas Homer's Achilles and Patroclus were not buried but cremated, in Iron-Age fashion, and honoured with gold urns instead of gold masks.[PARAGRAPH:2]No priestly class has yet been identified. Worshiper and worshiped are identified in seals, rings and votive figures through their gestures: worshipers fold their arms, or raise the right arm in greeting, or place a hand on the forehead. Deities lift both arms in the "epiphany gesture" or reach forward to give or receive. The pantheon of Mycenaean deities has been reassembled from inscriptions in Linear B found at Pylos and at post-palatial Mycenaean Knossos in Crete. Some of the deities' names are recognizably present in the Olympic pantheon of written myth. Others are not: Ares, for example, is represented only as "Enyalios" which was retained as an epithet. Apollo may be recognized at Knossos as PA-JA-WO ("Paian"). Far more prominent are A-TA-NA PO-TI-NI-JA (Athena Potnia, "Athena the Mistress"), E-RE-U-TI-JA (Eileithyia, later merely invoked during childbirth), Dionysus, and Poseidon, already the "Earth-Shaker", either with his consort Poseida, who was not retained in the transition to Classical Greece, or, at Pylos, with the "Two Goddesses", apparently Demeter and Persephone. The Erinyes or Furies are already present, as are the Winds.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mycenaean frescoes have been discovered in palace contexts, notably at Pylos, Mycenae, Orchomenos, Thebes, and Tiryns, and in a few non-palatial, perhaps privately-owned contexts. The earliest fresco decorations are of the LH IIA period (ca. 1500 BC). The subjects hold tenaciously to Minoan traditions, whether directly derived or through Cycladic intervention, and have in some cases been reduced to decorative formulas, embodying themes appropriate to their locations: lions and wingless griffins in audience chambers, processional figures in corridors, etc. In a change from the Minoan delight in the life of animals, the Mycenaean relation to nature is reflected in their depictions of animals which are shown only in relation to man or as victims of the hunt. Bull-jumping fresco panels appear at Mycenae and at Tiryns.[PARAGRAPH:2]Around 1100 BC, the Mycenaean civilization collapsed. Numerous cities were sacked, and the region entered what historians describe as a dark age with some Mycenaeans fleeing to Cyprus as well as other Greek islands and parts of Anatolia. During this period Greece experienced decreasing population and the limited literacy, connected with palace culture, disappeared. Historians have traditionally blamed this decline on an invasion or uprising by another wave of Greek people, the Dorians, who may have been a subjugated local people. Alternate theories for the decline also include natural disasters such as a series of earthquakes or large-scale drought, although these recent theories are more controversial.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Agamemnon[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Mycenae, Commander of the Achaeans in the Trojan War[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived: [\BOLD]c. 1250 BC[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2]Most of what is known of the ancient Greek hero Agamemnon is narrated in the Homeric legend of the ‘Iliad' and in the dramas of Aeschylus. The son of Atreus, who was the king of Mycenae in Greece, Agamemnon was probably a historical personage, a king who ruled either at Mycenae or at nearby Argos during the Trojan War. From the mythic tales of the ancient Greeks, however, it is impossible to separate fact from legend.[PARAGRAPH:2]The stories relate that Agamemnon was the brother of Menelaus, king of Sparta, whose wife, Helen, was carried off to Troy by Paris, a prince of that city in Asia Minor. This event led Agamemnon to muster the military might of the Greek city-states in a war of revenge. After the long war and the eventual destruction of Troy, he sailed home to his wife, Clytemnestra, and his family. Upon arriving, he was murdered either by his wife or by her lover, Aegisthus.[PARAGRAPH:2]Aegisthus then ruled Agamemnon's kingdom for a time, but the murder of Agamemnon was eventually avenged by his son Orestes with the help of his daughter Electra. The name Electra is now used in the psychological term 'Electra Complex', that a female child is generally attached to her father at a young age, feeling discontent towards her mother.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: I greet you warmly, [CT_NAME] of [CT_CIV_SHORT]. I myself am [OUR_NAME] of [OUR_CIV_SHORT]. The gods only protect the strong, [CT_NAME]. So, how strong is [CT_CIV_SHORT] exactly?
TEXT.French: Salutations ! Je suis [OUR_NAME], je règne sur l'[OUR_EMPIRE]. Je souhaite que nos deux grands peuples puissent vivre en paix.
TEXT.German: Seid gegrüßt! Ich bin [OUR_NAME], Staatsoberhaupt des [OUR_EMPIRE:3]es. Ich hoffe, unsere großartigen Völker werden in Frieden zusammenleben.
TEXT.Italian: Saluti! Io sono [OUR_NAME] dell'[OUR_EMPIRE]. Spero che i nostri due grandi popoli possano vivere in pace.
TEXT.Spanish: Saludos. ¡Soy [OUR_NAME], del [OUR_EMPIRE]! Espero que nuestros dos grandes pueblos puedan vivir en paz.

TEXT.English: Leave.
TEXT.French: Vos bavardages incessants ne nous amusent pas, [CT_NAME] !
TEXT.German: Euer bedeutungsloses Geschwafel amüsiert uns ganz und gar nicht, [CT_NAME]!
TEXT.Italian: I tuoi balbettii senza senso non sono affatto divertenti, [CT_NAME]!
TEXT.Spanish: ¡No nos hace gracia vuestra cháchara absurda, [CT_NAME]!

TEXT.English: A great victory will be won, [CT_NAME]... but that victory will not be yours!
TEXT.French: La guerre est très déplaisante, mais parfois nécessaire. Il apparaît que nous sommes dans cette situation, aussi devons-nous rejeter votre requête. Cette entrevue est terminée.
TEXT.German: Kriege sind eine höchst unangenehme Sache, manchmal aber auch unumgänglich. Und wie ich höre, ist das in diesem Fall so, deshalb muss ich Euer Anliegen zurückweisen. Diese Unterhaltung ist beendet!
TEXT.Italian: La guerra non è per niente piacevole, ma a volte è necessaria. Questa è una di quelle volte, perciò dobbiamo respingere le tue suppliche. L'udienza termina qui.
TEXT.Spanish: La guerra es harto desagradable, pero a veces resulta necesaria. Nos informan de que ésta es una de esas veces, así que debemos rechazar vuestras súplicas. La audiencia ha terminado.

TEXT.English: [CT_NAME], friend of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] peoples! I see you have sailed across many seas to see me. What is it that you need?
TEXT.French: Je vous souhaite la bienvenue ! Venez, allons détruire nos ennemis du haut de nos chars et laissons cinquante mille cadavres sur le champ de bataille pour le festin des corbeaux !
TEXT.German: Willkommen! Lasst uns unsere Streitwagen anspannen und unsere Feinde vernichten! Mögen die Gefallenen auf dem Schlachtfeld ein Festmahl für die Geier sein!
TEXT.Italian: Salve, ti do il benvenuto! Montiamo sulle bighe e distruggiamo i nemici, lasceremo sul campo di battaglia solamente i cadaveri perché se ne sfamino i corvi!
TEXT.Spanish: ¡Os saludamos, camarada! Venga, montemos en los carros, destruyamos a nuestros enemigos y dejemos cincuenta mil cadáveres pudriéndose en el campo de batalla como pasto para los cuervos.

TEXT.English: Personally, I believe you have serious problems, [CT_NAME]. And that is coming from a man who had an entire family with serious problems.
TEXT.French: Bonjour, [CT_NAME]. A quoi devons-nous cette interruption inattendue ?
TEXT.German: Guten Tag, [CT_NAME]. Was beschert mir diese unerwartete Störung?
TEXT.Italian: Buongiorno a te, [CT_NAME]. A cosa dobbiamo questa interruzione inaspettata?
TEXT.Spanish: Buenos días tengáis, [CT_NAME]. ¿A qué debemos esta interrupción tan inesperada?

TEXT.English: Please?
TEXT.French: Les [CT_CIV_ADJ] sont dans le besoin, [CT_NAME]. J'espère que vous ne les décevrez pas.
TEXT.German: Das [CT_CIV_ADJ:3] Volk befindet sich in einer üblen Notlage, [CT_NAME]! Enttäuscht uns nicht!
TEXT.Italian: Il popolo [CT_CIV_ADJ:1] vive nell'indigenza, [CT_NAME]. Non deluderci.
TEXT.Spanish: El pueblo [CT_CIV_ADJ:1] tiene una gran necesidad, [CT_NAME]. No nos decepcionéis.

TEXT.English: A good friend should do as all good friends do - share. And more specifically, cave in to the demands of their friends.
TEXT.French: Nous avons des besoins, [CT_NAME]. Veuillez les satisfaire.
TEXT.German: Auch wir haben Bedürfnisse, [CT_NAME]! Und es ist an Euch, sie zu befriedigen!
TEXT.Italian: Abbiamo delle necessità, [CT_NAME]. Ti preghiamo di accettarle.
TEXT.Spanish: Tenemos necesidades, [CT_NAME]. Satisfacedlas, por favor.

TEXT.English: The gods favor the strong, [CT_NAME]. But I will favor you, [CT_NAME], regardless of the gods, [CT_NAME], if the weak [CT_CIV_SHORT] gives a small amount of tribute.
TEXT.French: Donnez aux [CT_CIV_SHORT] ce qui leur revient, [CT_NAME] ! Nous ne vous le demanderons pas deux fois.
TEXT.German: Gebt [CT_CIV_SHORT], was ihm zusteht, [CT_NAME]! Wir werden Euch kein zweites Mal darum bitten!
TEXT.Italian: Dona ciò che ti richiede [CT_CIV_SHORT:2], [CT_NAME]! Non te lo chiederemo una seconda volta!
TEXT.Spanish: ¡Dadle a [CT_CIV_SHORT] lo que le corresponde, [CT_NAME]! No os lo pediremos otra vez.

TEXT.English: This Mycenaean replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Warrior[COLOR_REVERT] unit is stronger and also slightly cheaper.
TEXT.French: Cette puissante unité montée est lente mais s'avère un adversaire redoutable pour les unités telles que l'archer monté.
TEXT.German: Diese mächtige frühe berittene Kampfeinheit ist eine langsame aber effektive Waffe gegen Berittene Bogenschützen und ähnliche Einheiten.
TEXT.Italian: Questa potente unità montata iniziale è lenta ma potente, ottima per contrastare le unità come gli arcieri a cavallo.
TEXT.Spanish: Esta poderosa unidad montada temprana es más lenta que otras unidades como los Arqueros a caballo, pero los contrarresta mucho mejor.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The e-qe-ta, or eqeta (equetai), literally, the companions (the knights), formed the entourage of the king. These were the warriors. For the Mycenaean warriors, offensive arms were made of bronze. Spears and javelins have been found, and also an assortment of swords of different sizes, designed for striking with the point and with the edge. Daggers and arrows, attesting to the existence of archery, compose the remainder of the armament found from the Mycenaean period.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'utilisation des éléphants pour la guerre a commencé en Inde et était connue des Perses au IVe siècle av. J.-C. C'est grâce à ses éléphants de guerre que Chandragupta parvint à vaincre Seleucos, le successeur d'Alexandre le Grand, et à fonder l'Empire maurya. Même si les éléphants africains de Carthage ont peu d'exploits à leur actif, leur présence dans l'armée d'Hannibal lors de la traversée des Alpes en 218 av. J.-C. leur a valu une réputation d'arme redoutable. L'importance tactique des éléphants repose beaucoup sur leur capacité à attaquer l'infanterie comme la cavalerie, et à inspirer la terreur. Bien que les armées indiennes aient utilisé l'éléphant jusqu'au XXe siècle, son utilité dans la pratique de la guerre a pris fin avec l'invention de la poudre à canon.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Kriegselefant wurde zuerst in Indien eingesetzt und war den Persern im 4. Jahrhundert vor Christus schon geläufig. Mit Hilfe von Kriegselefanten gelang es dem indischen König Chandragupta, die Truppen von Seleukos, dem Nachfolger Alexanders des Großen, zu besiegen und das Maurya-Reich zu begründen. Auch wenn die afrikanischen Kriegselefanten der Karthager nur wenig ausrichten konnten, so machten sie ihrem Ruf als gefürchtetes Kriegsgerät alle Ehre, als Hannibal seine Truppen mitsamt den Dickhäutern über die Alpen führte, um im Jahre 218 vor Christus in Rom einzufallen. Die taktische Bedeutung der Kriegselefanten resultiert zum großen Teil aus ihrer Eigenschaft, sowohl Fußsoldaten als auch die Kavallerie anzugreifen und in Panik zu versetzen. Das indische Militär setzte sie zwar noch bis zum 20. Jahrhundert aktiv ein, letztlich erging es ihnen am Ende aber wie vielen anderen traditionellen "Waffen": Ihr militärischer Nutzen endete mit dem verbreiteten Einsatz von Schießpulver.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'elefante da guerra fu usato per la prima volta in India e fu conosciuto dai Persiani intorno al quarto secolo a. C. Grazie a queste unità, Candra Gupta sconfisse il successore di Alessandro, Seleuco, e fondò l'Impero Maurya. Anche se gli elefanti da guerra africani di Cartagine non furono determinanti, la loro presenza nell'esercito di Annibale durante la sua traversata delle Alpi verso il cuore di Roma, nel 218 a. C., affermò la loro reputazione di arma temibile. Apparentemente, l'importanza tattica dell'elefante si basa in gran parte sulla sua predisposizione a caricare sia i fanti che la cavalleria, nonché sul panico che è in grado di suscitare. Malgrado sia stato usato nelle truppe indiane fino al XX secolo, alla pari di molte armi tradizionali, la sua utilità in guerra è cessata con la diffusione della polvere da sparo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los elefantes de guerra fueron utilizados por primera vez en la India, y los persas ya lo conocían hacia el siglo IV a. C. Utilizando elefantes de guerra, Chandragupta derrotó a Seleuco, sucesor de Alejandro, y fundó el imperio mauryan. Aunque estos animales no sirvieron de mucho a Cartago, su presencia en el ejército de Aníbal durante el cruce de los Alpes y la invasión de Roma en el año 218 a. C. bastó para cimentar su reputación como armas terribles. La importancia táctica de los elefantes derivaba aparentemente de su disposición a cargar tanto contra la infantería como contra la caballería, y del pánico que esto inspiraba. Aunque sirvieron en el ejército indio hasta el siglo XX, su utilidad real, al igual que ocurrió con muchas otras armas tradicionales, terminó con la difusión generalizada de la pólvora.

TEXT.English: [TAB]In Greece, the tholoi are a monumental Late Bronze Age development of either the Mycenaean chamber tombs or tumulus burials dating to the Middle Bronze Age. After about 1500 BCE, beehive tombs became more widespread. They were built as corbelled arches, with layers of stone placed closer together as the arch tapers toward the top of the tomb. The tombs usually contain more than one burial, in various places in the tomb either on the floor, in pits and cists or on stone-built or rock-cut benches, and with various grave goods. After a burial, the entrance to the tomb was filled in with soil, leaving a small mound with most of the tomb underground.
